excerpt: Bright vermillion columns support the roof of this Shinto shrine originally established in 768 A.D..
detail_description: Kasuga Taisha is a Shinto shrine located in Nara, Japan, known for its bright vermillion columns supporting the roof. Established in 768 A.D., it offers plenty of photo opportunities both inside and outside the pay area. The shrine's surroundings also provide numerous great spots for photography. The transfer of the national capital to Nagaoka-kyo led to the development of Naramachi as a temple town, with Kasuga Taisha becoming a prominent attraction.
name: Kasugataisha Shrine

excerpt: Landscaped, public park with ancient temples & the Nara National Museum of art, plus tame deer.
detail_description: Nara Park is a picturesque public park featuring ancient temples and the Nara National Museum of art, as well as friendly deer roaming freely. The park offers a variety of attractions including Todaiji, Kasuga Grand Shrine, Kohfukuji, Mt. Wakakusa, Nigatsu-do Temple, Toshodaiji Temple, and more.
name: Nara Park

excerpt: Complex of Buddhist temple halls & pagodas, plus an on-site museum showcasing national treasures.
detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Nara, Kofuku-ji Temple is a stunning complex that showcases the rich history and architectural beauty of Japan's Buddhist heritage. Originally established as Yamashina-dera in Kyoto back in 669, this temple has undergone several transformations before settling into its current form. Renamed Kofuku-ji after being relocated to Heijo-kyo, it became a significant site during both the Nara and Heian periods.
name: Kōfuku-ji

excerpt: Buddhist temple originally built in the mid-700s, with one of Japan's largest bronze Buddha statues.
detail_description: Tōdai-ji is a Buddhist temple in Nara, Japan, originally constructed in the mid-700s. It is home to one of Japan's largest bronze Buddha statues. The temple town of Tōdai-ji and Kasuga-Taisha Shrine contributed to the growth of Naramachi, which became a bustling area during the Edo period.
name: Tōdai-ji

excerpt: Founded in 1889, this national art museum features an extensive collection of Japanese Buddhist art.
detail_description: Nara National Museum, established in 1889, is a prominent national art museum showcasing an extensive collection of Japanese Buddhist art. Situated east of Kofuku-ji Temple within Nara-koen Park, the museum comprises two buildings. The older structure houses the Nara Butsuzo-kan (Hall of Buddhist Images), exhibiting the permanent collection of exquisite Buddhist images. On the other hand, the newer building hosts special temporary exhibits.
name: Nara National Museum

excerpt: In lively Naramachi, narrow streets are lined with Edo-era wooden machiya merchant townhouses, many transformed into museums, gift shops, guesthouses, and cozy ramen and sushi restaurants. It's home to ancient shrines such as the restored Gango-ji Temple, a World Heritage Site dating from the 6th century. Naramachi Mechanical Toy Museum has interactive exhibits, and family-run Harushika Sake offers brewery tours.
detail_description: Naramachi, located in Nara Prefecture, is a charming district characterized by its narrow streets lined with well-preserved Edo-era wooden merchant townhouses. Many of these historic buildings have been repurposed into museums, gift shops, guesthouses, and traditional eateries serving delicious ramen and sushi. The area is also home to ancient shrines such as the Gango-ji Temple, a World Heritage Site dating back to the 6th century.
name: Naramachi

excerpt: Sizable collection of ancient Chinese bronze wares, mirrors & seals, along with Korean pottery.
detail_description: Isuien Garden and Neiraku Museum is a must-visit destination in Nara, Japan. The garden, established centuries ago, is divided into two sections: the front garden from the 17th century and the rear garden from 1899. It features a Shakkei-style landscape design that incorporates the surrounding scenery into its beauty. The small yet fascinating Neiraku Art Museum within the garden showcases ancient Chinese bronze wares, mirrors, seals, and Korean pottery.
name: Isuien Garden and Neiraku Museum

excerpt: 1,122-foot tall hill with an annual festival called Yamayaki, where dead grass is burned.
detail_description: Mount Wakakusa is a 1,122-foot tall hill in Nara, Japan. It hosts the annual festival called Yamayaki, during which dead grass is burned. The hill offers stunning views and is a popular attraction among visitors to Nara Park. The area is also known for its wild deer population, with two types of deer residing in the region: "park deer" and "Mount Wakakusa deer." Both types primarily feed on various grasses found in the area.
name: Mount Wakakusa

excerpt: Serene classical Japanese garden on a quiet river with a wooden teahouse & striking autumn blooms.
detail_description: Yoshikien Garden is a tranquil and traditional Japanese garden located near the Nara Park attractions. It offers a serene escape with its classical design, wooden teahouse, and beautiful autumn flowers. The garden features various styles including moss gardens, pond gardens, and borrowed scenery landscapes. Visitors can enjoy moments of reflection while strolling through the well-maintained grounds before indulging in traditional refreshments at Isuien's tea house.
name: Yoshikien Garden

excerpt: Buddhist temple with frescoes, statues & the world's oldest wooden buildings on its grounds.
detail_description: Nestled in the serene town of Ikaruga, Horyu-ji Temple stands as a testament to Japan's rich Buddhist heritage. Founded in 607 AD by the influential Prince Shotoku, this remarkable site is not only one of the oldest temples in Japan but also boasts some of the world's most ancient wooden structures. As you wander through its grounds, you'll encounter stunning frescoes and intricate statues that showcase early Buddhist artistry.
name: Horyu-ji
address: 1-1 Horyuji Sannai, Ikaruga, Ikoma District, Nara 636-0115, Japan

excerpt: Nara is the capital of Japan’s Nara Prefecture, in south-central Honshu. The city has significant temples and artwork dating to the 8th century, when it was Japan’s capital. Deer roam in Nara Park, site of Tōdai-ji temple. Daibutsu, Tōdai-ji's 15m-high bronze Buddha, is displayed in a large wooden hall. On the park's east side is the Shinto shrine Kasuga Taisha, which dates to 768 A.D. and more than 3,000 lanterns.
detail_description: Nara, the historic capital of Japan's Nara Prefecture, is a treasure trove of cultural heritage nestled in south-central Honshu. This enchanting city boasts remarkable temples and exquisite artwork that date back to the 8th century when it served as Japan’s capital. A highlight is Nara Park, where friendly deer roam freely among visitors.
name: Nara

excerpt: Reconstruction of the 8th-century imperial palace that once stood on this site.
detail_description: Heijō Palace Site Historical Park is a reconstruction of the 8th-century imperial palace that served as the residence of the emperor during most of the Nara Period in Heijo-kyo, modern-day Nara. The palace was a large rectangular walled enclosure housing ceremonial and administrative buildings, modeled after Xian in China. Today, visitors can explore the foundations and reconstructions of this once significant site, gaining insight into Japan's ancient history and architectural heritage.
name: Heijō Palace Site Historical Park

excerpt: Hilltop hall, part of Tōdai-ji Buddhist temple, with sweeping views of Nara from its balcony.
detail_description: Todai-ji Nigatsu-do is a hilltop hall within the Tōdai-ji Buddhist temple complex, offering stunning panoramic views of Nara from its expansive balcony. It hosts the 'Omizutori' fire and water festival in March, a captivating event that lasts for the first two weeks of the month. The hall is easily accessible via an atmospheric walkway starting at the northeast corner of Todai-ji's Daibutsu-den Hall.
name: Todai-ji Nigatsu-do

detail_description: Sarusawa-ike Pond is a historic site located along Sanjo-dori in Nara, Japan. Dating back to the year 749, it was originally dug within the grounds of Kofuku-Ji temple. Despite its modest size, the pond offers a tranquil setting for a leisurely stroll under the graceful willow trees and cherry blossoms that bloom in spring.
name: Sarusawa Pond

excerpt: Originally built in 680, this Buddhist landmark was once one of the Seven Great Temples in Nara.
detail_description: Yakushi-ji, a significant Buddhist temple in Nara, was originally constructed in 680 and was once among the Seven Great Temples of the area. The site is known for its two pagodas, each representing different periods of Japanese history. The East Pagoda, built in 1285, is admired for its asymmetrical design and has been likened to 'frozen music' by an early Western specialist in Japanese art.
name: Yakushi-ji

excerpt: Area of ancient maple & cedar trees, with mountain trails passing waterfalls & Buddhist statues.
detail_description: Nestled in the eastern mountain range of Nara city, Mount Kasuga Primeval Forest is a 498-meter-high expanse of ancient maple and cedar trees spanning approximately 250 hectares. This sacred site has been preserved since ancient times as a place of worship for the mountain god of Kasuga Taisha shrine. Visitors can explore the area's natural beauty by walking along the 9.4km esplanade that surrounds the forest, passing by waterfalls and Buddhist statues.
name: Mt. Kasuga Primeval Forest

detail_description: Asuka, located approximately 25 kilometers south of Downtown Nara, is a rural area known for its historical significance in early Japanese history. It was where the Yamato Dynasty established its power in ancient Japan. The landscape features rolling hills, rice paddies, and sporadic dwellings, offering visitors a glimpse into the region's rich past and picturesque natural surroundings.
name: Asuka

excerpt: Buddhist temple complex known for its 8th-century Golden Hall, acknowledged as a national treasure.
detail_description: Toshodai-ji is a Buddhist temple complex in Nara, Japan, renowned for its 8th-century Golden Hall, considered a national treasure. Established in 759 by the Chinese priest Ganjin, it was pivotal in the introduction and development of Buddhism in Japan. The main hall underwent extensive renovation and reconstruction over nearly ten years before reopening in late 2009.
name: Toshodai-ji

excerpt: Tranquil shrine set amid gardens with a pond & spring cherry blossoms, known for ice offerings.
detail_description: Himuro Shrine is a serene Shinto shrine located in Nara, known for its beautiful gardens featuring a pond and spring cherry blossoms. The shrine is home to the impressive shidare-zakura cherry tree, which signals the arrival of spring in Nara with its early bloom. Visitors can also admire other species of sakura contrasting with the crimson red torii gate at the entrance.
name: Himuro Shrine

detail_description: Tamukeyama Hachimangu Shrine, located near Nigatsu-do in Nara Park, is a serene and less-visited destination. Established in 749, this small but significant shrine is dedicated to the deity Hachiman and enshrines three emperors and an empress. The peaceful atmosphere, adorned with beautiful ema and lanterns featuring symbols of peace, offers a tranquil experience away from the bustling tourist spots nearby.
name: Tamukeyama Hachimangu

detail_description: Kintetsu-Nara Station is conveniently located near Nara Park, making it easily accessible for visitors to explore the area. The station is a starting point for various activities such as visiting temples and museums, feeding the famous deer in the park, and enjoying cherry blossoms at Mount Wakakusa. Travelers can also take a 35-minute limited rapid express train from Osaka-Namba to reach Kintetsu-Nara Station quickly.
name: Kintetsu-Nara Station

excerpt: 8th-century Buddhist temple complex housing statues of the Twelve Heavenly Generals.
detail_description: Shin Yakushi-ji Temple, located in Nara, is a revered 8th-century Buddhist temple complex known for its Twelve Heavenly Generals statues. This historical site offers a serene atmosphere away from the bustling attractions of Nara. Visitors can admire the masterpieces of Japanese Buddhist art, including the collection of Guardian Deities statues. The temple is dedicated to the Healing Buddha and features a large wooden statue along with Late Nara sculptures.
name: Shin Yakushi-ji

detail_description: Nara Station is a bustling hub for travelers, offering convenient access to the city's main attractions. Visitors can witness the spectacular Hanaougi Hono Gyoretsu parade, which kicks off at 17:00 and features traditional Nara-era attire and impressive imperial carriages. For those seeking relaxation, a nearby hotel provides spacious rooms and access to natural hot spring baths.
name: Nara Station

excerpt: Historic Buddhist temple featuring a large Buddha statue & deer roaming the grounds.
detail_description: Todai-ji Daibutsuden, also known as the Great Buddha Hall, is a historic Buddhist temple in Nara. It houses a large Buddha statue and is surrounded by deer roaming the grounds of Nara Park. The colossal statue has been a symbol of Nara for over 1,000 years. The temple's history dates back to the introduction of Buddhism and has undergone major repairs to maintain its original state.
name: Todai-ji Daibutsuden (Great Buddha Hall)

excerpt: Covered shopping arcade featuring casual eateries & retailers for souvenirs, clothing & housewares.
detail_description: Higashimuki Shopping Street is a covered arcade filled with casual eateries and shops offering souvenirs, clothing, and housewares. Visitors can find unique souvenirs featuring deer or monks, as well as local items like calligraphy brushes and Nara Sarashi fabrics. The street is known for its local delicacies such as Narazuke pickles and kaki-no-hazushi sushi.
name: Higashimuki Shopping Street

excerpt: Well-known store featuring traditional Japanese mochi rice cakes & making demonstrations.
detail_description: Nakatanidou is a well-known store near Nara Park that specializes in traditional Japanese mochi rice cakes. The shop offers making demonstrations where visitors can witness the high-speed process of mochi-pounding, adding to the experience of enjoying this beloved dessert. Despite its unassuming appearance, Nakatanidou draws crowds with its efficient and friendly service, offering warm and fragrant mochi with red bean filling.
name: Nakatanidou

excerpt: Riverside trail in a forested valley, once a training ground for ninjas, with lots of waterfalls.
detail_description: Nestled in the scenic Iga region of Mie Prefecture, west of Tsu and bordering Nara Prefecture, Akame 48 Waterfalls is a top attraction. This stunning series of cascades, some reaching up to 30 meters high, is a hiker's paradise. The four-kilometer trail takes you through lush mountain greenery and ancient forests alongside clear mountain streams.
name: Akame 48 Waterfalls

excerpt: Archaeological remnants of a 16th-century castle situated in a park popular for cherry blossoms.
detail_description: Koriyama Castle Ruins, located in a park famous for its cherry blossoms, are the remains of a 16th-century castle. The site is home to Yamato Koriyama Castle, known for its goldfish and historical significance dating back to the Sengoku Period. Despite being destroyed during the Meiji era, the inner moat and stone walls remain well-preserved. The castle grounds are particularly stunning in spring when numerous cherry blossom trees bloom.
name: Koriyama Castle Ruins

detail_description: Higashimuki Shopping Street, along with Mochiidono shopping arcades and traditional local shops in Naramachi, offers a delightful shopping experience for those seeking high-quality Japanese items. The charming old town quarter is home to longstanding shops, each offering its own unique treasures. Take your time exploring the area to uncover hidden gems and make the most of your Nara shopping adventure.
name: Higashimuki Shopping St

detail_description: Mizuya Chaya, established in 1948, is located at the entrance of Kasuga Shrine and offers stunning waterfront views of Miyagawa River. The building, a well-preserved thatched cottage from the Taisho Era, provides a serene escape with its vibrant red maple surroundings during autumn. Visitors can enjoy affordable culinary delights such as Udon with Edible Wild Plants and Udon with Fried Tofu Seasoned.
name: Mizuya Chaya

detail_description: Nara Deer Hostel is a small, quiet, and clean accommodation located 25 minutes' walk from Ukimi-do Hall Bridge, close to Naramachi. The hostel offers rooms with amenities like a microwave and fridge. Guests have praised the location for being within walking distance of transportation stations. The common lounge is available until 10 p.m. daily and provides a cozy space for backpackers to socialize.
name: Nara Deer Hostel

excerpt: Ancient Buddhist temple in a garden setting featuring a sloping tiled roof & a tranquil atmosphere.
detail_description: Gango-ji is an ancient Buddhist temple located in a serene garden setting. During the Edo period, it was a hub for various businesses and is now recognized as a world heritage site. The surrounding area evolved into a bustling city of commerce and industry. Gango-ji is part of a collection of sites that represent a significant shift in Japanese history during the 8th century, showcasing cultural and political developments during Nara's time as Japan's capital from 710 to 784.
name: Gango-ji

excerpt: Tiny 8th-century temple rebuilt after a fire in 1135, showcasing revered Buddhist icons & artifacts.
detail_description: Akishino-dera Temple, a small 8th-century temple that was reconstructed after a fire in 1135, is a serene and lesser-known gem. The temple features an array of revered Buddhist icons and artifacts, including exquisite murals and sculptures influenced by both esoteric Buddhist and Hindu traditions. Its tranquil garden and the impressive statue of Dainichi Nyorai offer visitors a peaceful retreat amidst lush surroundings.
name: Akishino-dera

excerpt: Ornate carved tower first built by the Fujiwara clan in 730, now a symbolic landmark of Nara.
detail_description: The Kofuku-ji Gojunoto, or Five-Story Pagoda, stands as a magnificent testament to Japan's rich history and architectural prowess. Originally erected in 730 by Empress Komyoh, this stunning structure reaches an impressive height of 50.1 meters, making it the second tallest wooden pagoda in the country.
name: Kōfuku-ji Gojūnotō (Five Story Pagoda)

excerpt: Charming, poetry-themed botanical garden hosting an annual Japanese classical music festival.
detail_description: Nestled next to the Kasuga Shrine, Manyo Botanical Gardens, also known as Kasuga Taisha Garden, is a charming and poetic destination. This ancient garden is famous for its inclusion in the Manyo-shu collection of poems and features over 150 varieties of flowering plants. With approximately 300 different plant species from Japan's ancient times, it stands as the country's oldest botanical garden.
name: Manyo Botanical Gardens

excerpt: Founded in 765 CE, this is the main temple for the  Shingon Risshu sect of Buddhism.
detail_description: Saidai-ji, founded in 765 CE, is the main temple for the Shingon Risshu sect of Buddhism. It's one of several Buddhist temples in the city, along with Shinto shrines like Himuro Shrine and Kasuga Shrine. The temple offers a serene escape from the city center and provides a glimpse into local religious and cultural traditions. Visitors can also enjoy park areas surrounding many of these sites.
name: Saidai-ji

excerpt: Museum & shop featuring a small collection of local crafts, decorative ornaments & other artwork.
detail_description: Naramachi Shiryo-kan Museum is a must-visit spot in Naramachi, offering a glimpse into the local history and community. The museum showcases a diverse collection of traditional, contemporary, and post-modern crafts, decorative ornaments, and artwork. Visitors can also explore the on-site gift shop to purchase unique local crafts. Additionally, it is known as Koshin-san and is often featured on Nara TV.
name: Naramachi Shiryo-kan Museum

excerpt: Photography exhibits & a gift shop in a glass-walled space designed in harmony with the environment.
detail_description: The Irie Taikichi Memorial Museum of Photography in Nara City, Japan is a must-visit for photography enthusiasts. The museum, previously known as the Nara City Museum of Photography, showcases an impressive collection of Japanese photography in a beautifully designed glass-walled space that blends seamlessly with its surroundings. This memorial museum was opened to honor the works of native photographer Irie Taikichi, who captured the essence of Nara through his compelling photographs depicting local culture, events, and Buddhist statues.
name: Irie Taikichi Memorial Museum of Photography Nara City

detail_description: Kairyuo-ji Temple is a serene and beautiful ancient temple known for its tranquil atmosphere. The Main Hall, designated as a National Treasure, showcases stunning architectural details from the Nara period. The temple is said to have a dragon motif due to its association with the Sea Dragon King Sutra. Its auspicious origins date back to 710 when it was established as a residence and later acquired by Fujiwara no Fuhito.
name: Kairyuo-ji

excerpt: Unassuming art museum with a permanent collection of Japanese works & rotating exhibits.
detail_description: The Nara Prefectural Museum of Art, located near Kohfuku-ji Temple in Nara Park, houses a diverse collection of over 4,100 Japanese and east-Asian art pieces. These include ukiyo-e block prints and paintings from the Edo era and earlier, as well as modern paintings, sculptures, and other works. The museum regularly features special exhibitions throughout the year.
name: Nara Prefectural Museum of Art

excerpt: Outdoor installations by artists Inoue Fukichi & Dani Karavan set amid pines, ponds & grass mounds.
detail_description: Nestled in the heart of Muro village, Murou Art Forest is an enchanting open-air museum featuring outdoor installations by renowned artists Inoue Fukichi and Dani Karavan. Inspired by sculptor Bukichi Inoue, the park showcases a diverse collection of contemporary sculptures designed by Dani Karavan in 2006, all centered around the theme of 'Harmony between Nature and Art.' Despite being relatively undiscovered, this vast space offers a serene experience without large crowds.
name: Murou Art Forest

detail_description: Nestled on the slopes of Mount Shigi, Gyokuzoin is a historic temple offering visitors an immersive experience in Japanese spiritual heritage. The temple complex features stunning traditional architecture and sweeping city vistas. Guests can stay in a shukubo, participate in morning prayer rituals, and engage in training experiences focused on healing and spiritual growth. The temple's hospitable monks provide insight into the ceremonies, while traditional meals add to the authentic experience.
name: Gyokuzoin
address: 2280 Shigisan, Heguri, Ikoma District, Nara 636-0923, Japan

excerpt: Ikaruga is a town in Ikoma District, Nara, Japan. As of 31 December 2024, the town had an estimated population of 28,036 in 12,292 households, and a population density of 2000 persons per km². Wikipedia.
detail_description: Ikaruga, located in Ikoma District, Nara, Japan, is renowned for its ancient Buddhist temples such as Hōryū-ji and Hokki-ji. These temples are collectively designated as UNESCO World Heritage Sites. The town also boasts other historic temples like Hōrin-ji, all contributing to the rich cultural heritage of Ikaruga.
name: Ikaruga

excerpt: This rebuilt 8th-century temple serves as the primary temple for the Buzan sect of Shingon Buddhism.
detail_description: Hasedera Temple, a reconstructed 8th-century temple, is the primary temple for the Buzan sect of Shingon Buddhism. Founded in 686 and expanded in 727, it houses the golden 11-faced Kannon of Mercy Bodhisattva Statue. The main hall sits high on a mountain slope and is accessed by around 400 covered and lantern-lined Nobori-ro cloister stairs. The temple's picturesque hillside location offers breathtaking views of surrounding mountains and valleys.
name: Hasedera Temple

excerpt: Ikoma is a city in the northwestern end of Nara Prefecture in the Kansai region of Japan. It was founded on November 1, 1971. As of September 1, 2023, the city has an estimated population of 117,259, with 51,478 households. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Ikoma, located in the northwestern part of Nara Prefecture in the Kinki region of Japan, was established on November 1, 1971. With an estimated population of 117,259 and 51,478 households as of September 1, 2023, it is a vibrant city offering a mix of modern amenities and traditional charm.
name: Ikoma

excerpt: Tenri is a city located in Nara Prefecture, Japan. As of 30 September 2024, the city had an estimated population of 60,890 in 29456 households, and a population density of 700 persons per km². The total area of the city is 86.42 km². Wikipedia.
detail_description: Tenri is a city in Nara Prefecture, Japan, established in 1954 and named after the Tenrikyo religion. With a population of around 66,866 people, it's home to the headquarters of Tenrikyo. The city offers a popular restaurant known for its affordable high-quality meat dishes, including rare beef cuts and Wagyu beef hormone.
name: Tenri

detail_description: Kofuku-ji Kokuhokan, also known as the National Treasure Hall, is a remarkable facility housing an impressive collection of national treasures. Among its notable attractions are ancient statues of the 10 Disciples and Asura, as well as a towering 1000-armed Kannon that leaves visitors in awe. While photography is not permitted inside due to tight security measures, the sculptures are truly captivating.
name: Kofukuji Temple National Treasure Museum

detail_description: The Kintetsu Nara Station Tourist Information Centre is a convenient spot for travelers to gather information about the city's main attractions. The staff at the center are known for their helpfulness and provide a wealth of the latest information, making it easier for visitors to plan their itinerary. Additionally, there are plenty of pamphlets available about tourist spots and campaign coupons that can be used.
name: Kintetsu Nara station Tourist Information Centre
address: 近鉄奈良駅ビル, 29 Higashimuki Nakamachi, Nara, 630-8215, Japan

excerpt: Storied & imposing temple with exhibits on its history, Buddha statues & extensive gardens.
detail_description: The Todai-ji Museum, established in 2011, serves as a venue to display the treasures of the Todai-ji Temple. It features rotating exhibits on the temple's history, Buddha statues, and lush gardens. Despite facing disasters and fires throughout its long history, the museum offers a comfortable space for visitors with amenities like air conditioning and restrooms. While some find the exhibit information lacking and note occasional closures of the cafe, many appreciate it as a welcome respite from summer heat.
name: Todai-ji Museum
address: Japan, 〒630-8208 Nara, Suimoncho, 100, 東大寺総合文化センター内
